turns.speaker: SOPHOMORE
turns.text: Hey!  I'm getting a little tired of this.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You volunteered, didn't you?  Aren't we paying you for this?

turns.speaker: SOPHOMORE
turns.text: Yeah, but I didn't know you were going to give me electric shocks.  What are you trying to prove?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'm studying the effect of negative reinforcement on ESP ability.

turns.speaker: SOPHOMORE
turns.text: I'll tell you the effect!  It pisses me off!

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Then my theory was correct.

turns.speaker: STREET PUNK
turns.text: Hey, Mister!  Can I see those guns?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: They're not guns.  They're particle throwers.

turns.speaker: STREET PUNK
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.  I just want to see 'em.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I couldn't do that.  You might hurt someone.

turns.speaker: STREET PUNK
turns.text: Wait!  Wait!  Let me ask you something.  If you like shot Superman with those guns, would he feel it or what?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: On Earth -- no.  But on Krypton we could slice him up like Oscar Mayer Bologna.

turns.speaker: STREET PUNK
turns.text: Wow!

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Were you recently in the bathroom?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: What on earth gave you that idea?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: The wet towels, residual moisture on your lower limbs and hair, the redness in your cheeks indicating ...

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: You're a regular Sherlock Holmes.  Now what do you want?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: When you were in the bathroom, did you notice anything that was yellow and unusually smelly?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Oh!  You're here.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What have you got, Egon?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Oh, this is big, Peter.  This is very big. There's definitely something here.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Egon, somehow this reminds me of the time you tried to drill a hole in your head.  Do you remember that?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Spengler, are you serious about actually catching a ghost?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I'm always serious.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Wow!

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Just for your information, Ray, the interest payments alone for the first five years come to over $75,000.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Will you guys relax?  We are on the threshold of establishing the indispensable defense science of the next decade - Professional Paranormal Investigations and Eliminations.  The franchise rights alone will make us wealthy beyond your wildest dreams.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Generally, you don't see that kind of behavior in a major appliance.  What do you think, Egon?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: She's telling the truth -- or at least she thinks she is.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Did you see anything?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Didn't see anything,  Didn't get anything. Nice girl - no ghost.  I'm starting to worry.  You said your graph was pointing to something big.  You told me things were going to start popping.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Something was definitely here.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Yeah, I can smell it.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Wait!  Wait!  There's something I forgot to tell you.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Don't cross the beams.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Trust me.  It will be bad.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What do you mean "bad?"

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: It's hard to explain, but try to imagine all life as you know it stopping instantaneously and finding yourself confined forever in another dimension.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: It's Peter, Egon.  I've got a problem.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'm with Dana Barrett and she's floating three feet off the bed.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Does she want to be?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I don't think so.  It's more of that Gozer thing.  She says she's the Gatekeeper.  Does that make any sense to you?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Some.  I just met the Keymaster.  He's here with me now.  Venkman?  Are you there?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.  I was just thinking.  It probably wouldn't be a good idea for them to get together at this point.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I agree.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You have to keep him there.  Do whatever you have to, but don't let him leave,  He could be very dangerous.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: All right.  I'll try.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'll spend the night here and get back first thing in the morning.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: All right, Peter.  Good night.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: He wants to shut down the storage grid.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: If you turn that thing off we won't be responsible for the consequences.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Where's the Keymaster?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Oh, shit!

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Of course!  Ivo Shandor,  I saw his name in Tobin's SPIRIT GUIDE.  He started a secret society in 1920.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Let me guess -- Gozer Worshippers.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Yes.  After the First World War Shandor decided that society was too sick to survive.  And he wasn't alone.  He had close to a thousand followers when he died.  They conducted rituals, bizarre rituals, intended to bring about the end of the world.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: She said he was "the Destructor."

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Gozer.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: You talked to Gozer?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Get a grip on yourself, Egon.  I talked to Dana Barrett and she referred to Gozer as the Destructor.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What now?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Full-stream with strogon pulse.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: On the count of three!  One ... Two ...

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: No!  Them!  Shoot them!  Cross the beams.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: No!  You said crossing the beams would be BAD.  It'll kill her!  And us!

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Life is just a state of mind.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: But it's my favorite state.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: You know, Peter, this could be a past life experience intruding on the present.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Or even a race memory, stored in the collective unconscious.  And I wouldn't rule out clairvoyance or telepathic contact either.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I just realized something.  We've never had a completely successful test with any of the equipment.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I blame myself.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Sorry, Buddy!

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: We'd better adjust our streams.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Ray!  Where are you?  Are you all right?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: God, it's ugly!

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: It's working!

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Easy ... Easy ... I'm going to throw in my trap now.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Set entry grid.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Neutronize.  System shut.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I've got to sleep.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I need two new purge valves.  How's the grid around the storage facility holding up?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I'm worried, Ray.  It's getting crowded in there.  And all my recent data points to something big on the bottom.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: What happened??!!!?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: The storage facility blew.  This one ...  ... shut off the protection grid.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Look at the structure of the roof cap.  It looks exactly like the kind of telemetry tracker NASA uses to identify dead pulsars in other galaxies.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: And look at this, Peter  Cold-riveted girders with selenium cores.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: You mean if I stand here and concentrate on the image of Roberto Clemente, Gozer will appear as Roberto Clemente and wipe us out?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: That appears to be the case.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Excuse me for a minute.  Ray, I'm right in the middle of something here.  Can you come back in about an hour?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Peter, at 1:40 this afternoon at the main branch of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, ten people witnessed a free-roaming, vaporous, full-torso apparition.  It blew books from shelves at twenty feet away.  Scared the socks off some poor librarian.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Sure.  That's great, Ray.  I think you should get down there right away and check it out.  Let me know what happens.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: No, this one's for real, Peter.  Spengler went down there and took some PKE readings. Right off the top of the scale.  Buried the needle.  We're close this time. I can feel it.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Spengler and I have charted every psychic occurrence in the Tri-State area for the past two years.  The graph we came up with definitely points to something big.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Ray, as your friend I have to tell you I think you've really gone around the bend on this ghost stuff.  You've been running your ass off for two years checking out every schizo in the Five Boroughs who thinks he's had an experience.  And what have you seen?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: What do you mean by "seen?"

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Looked at with your eyes.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Well, I was at an unexplained multiple high-altitude rockfall once.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Uh-huh.  I've heard about the rockfall, Ray. I think you've been spending too much time with Spengler.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: It looks like a big pair of breasts and a pot belly.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I told you it's real.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What do we do now?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I don't know.  Talk to it.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What do I say?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Anything!  Just make contact.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Hey, Lady?  Lady!  Can you talk?  Who are you?   This is not working.  Think of something else.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Okay.  Okay.  I got it.  I know what to do. Stay close.  I have a plan.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: "Get her?"  That was your whole plan?  You call that science?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I guess I got a little overexcited.  Wasn't it incredible!  I'm telling you, this is a first.  You know what this could mean to the University?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Oh, yeah.  This could be bigger than the microchip.  They'll probably throw out the entire engineering department and turn their building over to us.  We're probably the first serious scientists to ever molest a dead old lady.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: If you guys are right, if we can actually trap a ghost and hold it somehow, I think I could win the Nobel Prize.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: If anyone deserves it, it's Spengler and me. We're doing all the hard research and designing the equipment.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Yeah, but I introduced you guys.  You never would've met if not for me.  That's got to be worth something.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: You said you floored 'em at the Regents' meeting.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Ray, I apologize.  I guess my confidence in the Regents was misplaced.  They did this to Galileo, too.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: This is like a major disgrace.  Forget M.I.T. or Stanford now ... they wouldn't touch us with a three-meter cattle prod.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You're always so worried about your reputation.  We don't need the University. Einstein did his best stuff while he was working as a patent clerk.'They can't stop progress.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Do you know what a patent clerk makes?  I liked the University.  They gave us money, they gave us the facilities and we didn't have to produce anything!  I've worked in the private sector.  They expect results. You've never been out of college.  You don't know what it's like out there.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Let me tell you, Ray, everything in life happens for a reason.  Call it fate, call it luck, Karma, whatever.  I think we were destined to get kicked out of there.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: For what purpose?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: To go into business for ourselves.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You'll never regret this, Ray.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: My parents left me that house, I was born there.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You're not going to lose the house. Everybody has three mortgages these days.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: But at nineteen percent interest!  You didn't even bargain with the guy.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: But most people are afraid to even report these things.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Maybe.  But no one ever advertised before.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Wow!  Does this pole still work?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: This might do ... I don't know ... it just seems kind of "pricey" for a fixer-upper, don't you think?  We're trying to keep our costs down.  You know how it is when you're starting a new company.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Everybody can relax.  I found the car.  How do you like it?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Do you think it's wide enough?  How much?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Fourteen hundred.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Why don't I check out the building?  It may have a history of psychic turbulence.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Good idea.  Were any other words spoken that you remember?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: How was your date?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: It wasn't a date.  It was an investigation.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: They will.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Do you know when that might be?  We're on the brink of a very serious cash-flow problem.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: So do I.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: No sense worrying about it now.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Sure.  Each of us is wearing an unlicensed nuclear accelerator on our back.  No problem.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I'm getting high readings near the air vents.  It must be using the duct system to get around.  See, I told you we'd get something.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: So far all we got is a shit smell on the twelfth floor and we almost fried a Puerto Rican bellboy.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: All right.  Let's cool the negative vibes. These things can sense them.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Ray -- Something's here.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Where are you, Pete?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Third floor.  Get down here,

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Sit tight.  I'm on my way.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Well, hurry up.  The needle's going wild.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: It's here, Ray.  It's looking at me.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Don't move.  It won't hurt you.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I don't know.  I'm just guessing.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Boy, that was a rough one.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I can't take much more of this.  The pace is killing me.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Egon, how's the grid around the storage facility holding up?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: It's not good, Pete.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I guess they don't build them like they used to, huh?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: No!  Nobody ever built them like this!  The architect was either an authentic whacko or a certified genius.  The whole building is like a huge antenna for pulling in and concentrating psychokinetic energy.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Who was the architect?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: He's listed on the blueprints as I. Shandor.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: It doesn't seem to have slowed him down any.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I don't think it's Shandor.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: As a duly-constituted representative of the City of New York, and on behalf of the County and State of New York, the United States of America, the Planet Earth and all its inhabitants, I hereby order you to cease and desist any and all supernatural activity and return at once to your place of origin or next parallel dimension.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Well, that ought to do it.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Agile bastard, isn't he?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Forget the trapping!  Just blast him!

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I couldn't help it!  It just popped in there!

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What?  What popped in there?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Look!

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: AND YOU CAME UP WITH THAT?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: The Stay-Puft Marshmallow Man!  He was on all the packages we used to buy when I was a kid.  We used to roast Stay-Puft marshmallows at Camp Waconda!

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Great!  The marshmallows are about to get their revenge.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Very impressive resume.  Electronic countermeasures, Strategic Air Command ... Black belt in Karate ... Small arms expert ... Mr. Zeddemore, as you may have heard, we locate ghosts and spirits, trap them with streams of concentrated quantum energy and remove them from people's homes, offices and places of worship.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Yeah, I heard that.  Now tell me what you really do.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Hey man.  What is it you're so involved with there?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Uh ... Oh these are blueprints of the structural ironwork in Dana Barrett's apartment building ... And they're most unusual.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Are you a Christian, Ray?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Mmmhmmm.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Me, too.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Boy!  Solid cores of shielded Selenium .325.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Do you believe in God?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: No.  But I liked Jesus' style.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Me, too. Parts of the Bible are great.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: The whole roof cap was fabricated with a magnesium-tungsten alloy.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Ray, do you remember something in the Bible about a day when the dead would rise up from their graves?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: And the seas would boil ...

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Right.  And the sky would fall ...

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Judgement Day ...

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Yeah, Judgement Day.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Every ancient religion had its own myth about the end of the world.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Well, has it ever occurred to you that the reason you've been so busy lately is because the dead have been rising from their graves?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: You don't have to worry about that with us, sir.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Right.  We'll believe anything.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Stantz?  You okay in there?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: LATER, MAN!!

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: What's he talking about?  Choose what?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: What do you mean "choose?"  We don't understand.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Where are we now, Commodus?  Can you see the camp?  My Gods!  The air is turning into ice!

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: We're nearly there, Lucilla.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: That's what you told me two days ago!

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Will you please get back in your wagon?  And stay there?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: I'm tired of being stuck in that wagon.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: More wine, sister?  Surely you can drink more than that.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: I was suddenly thinking about going to bed.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Oh, stay...  Don't you want to join the chorus of praises for Narcissus' glory?  Just remember, he is a married man.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Quite so.  Narcissus and his courageous men; may they live long to serve Rome...

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: And Caesar!  Let's not forget to serve Caesar!

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Don't you think you should at least wave?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Why?  Then they'll notice when I'm gone.  Well.  I'm making a public appearance aren't I?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: They hate me, they really hate me don't they?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Maybe you should get married.  Pick one of your cousins, it would demonstrate a profound stability.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I should at least have you, don't you think?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: If you get me pregnant with a boy he'll be a double direct heir and will end up killing you for the throne.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Did Narcissus die today?  Wasn't this his day to die?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: I'm sure, I don't know.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: No one in Rome has ever heard of him.  Do you want to remind those few in the Senate who have?  The whole sordid thing is far beneath your position to begin with.  Forget about him.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Let some time pass... then ask, quietly, without anyone knowing it comes from me.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Those are priceless sculptures.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I want every single thing that belonged to my father out of this house!  If it's worth something then sell it!

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: It's disgusting!  Animals!  I had to come here under armed guard.  Slaves -- get this junk out of my sight.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Commodus is heaving out every thing that belonged to our father.  Except that he can't heave out his ghost.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: How about in the forum.  Right in front of the Senate.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: If I may be so bold...

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: For the gods, spit it out!

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Why not do it in the Colosseum?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Kill him!  Tribuus -- execute that bastard.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: You can't do that!  You came here to turn the crowd around not make them hate you.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Tribuus... tomorrow.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: You're coming back?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I have to come back.  If I don't come back the people will think I'm a coward.  Tribuus, tomorrow he dies -- I want his blood on the sand.  Do you understand?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Where have you been?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Taking my pleasure.  Do I need to clear my lovers with you?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: You must start clearing everything with me -- especially your lovers.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Why are you so surly -- you've won, brother.  The people have bread and the city is quiet.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: What is that... wailing?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: The fans of Narcissus.  They were on vigil outside the school of Proximo. They believe he's dying.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Now that is a happy sound! Tomorrow, I want the citizens -- my people -- back in the arena.  The Gods know, I'm tired.  Come to bed, now; tonight we're celebrating.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Now that we're done with that infatuation forever.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: If I ever loved Narcissus it wasn't like you want.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: But I get what I want, always, don't I?

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: "... encased in the armor of a demigod, Narcissus The Good continues his impossible climb in the arena where he was unjustly cast..."

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Yes?  Go on!

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: "... by the emperor of Rome.  This writer asks:  between a Senate that debates truth until they choke, an Emperor who has the birth sign of a woman, is it possible there is more virtue within the arena than without?"

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Tell Lykas to send a retiarius and a Samnite to help Tiger.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: You can't do that... listen to the mood of the crowd.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I want that bastard dead!

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: You want control of the crowd -- you can't get it by killing their hero.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I am their hero!

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Not yet, dear brother...

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Send them out!

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Lykas, pick a man.  Someone who will look good.  Jerses I want it built up in the Daily Action...

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: Do you want posters, too?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Damn him!  I should have killed him on the front -- I let you talk me out of that.

turns.speaker: LUCILLA
turns.text: You would have had a full scale revolt on your hands.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: What have I got now?  It's exactly as if there were two emperors. Because of this the people have two minds.  He is their champion.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Welcome back from your great triumph Narcissus Meridas.  My father sends his heart felt praise.  Sadly, Marcus is in dark humors -- nothing to worry about, but he needs rest. Likely just the weather.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Respectfully Caesar, Quintus and I must report.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Of course, but not now.  However, if he continues to be unwell, you may report to me.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Do you expect Marcus to be well enough by morning for an audience?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: That's difficult to say, general.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Perhaps, Master Galen, you may say.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Then you'd be out of a job.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Gladly Caesar.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Or perhaps into a new one.  But here's to your God and the courage of our legions...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: I back Rome against all her enemies -- if that answer disappoints you, I'm not a politician...

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Oh, but with the army behind you, you could become extremely political.  Not a Republican by any chance?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I would say there's nothing more dangerous than a man who knows what 'right' is.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: The dangerous man, Caesar, is the man who doesn't care.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: But they're not destroyed, not yet.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Do we really need to repair this fort?  It seems like an expensive undertaking.  I propose we burn it to the ground.  That way if the Germans cross the Danube here there will be nothing to help them build an offensive position.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: You and my father have become very close.  Perhaps one day I may say the same for us.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: You flatter me, Caesar.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Being as close, I'm certain you've noticed what we all have noticed.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Caesar?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: That this illness has clouded his mind.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I'm ordering a general stand-down in preparation for withdrawal back across the Danube.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: We have to stop the Germans now!

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Forgive me, Caesar, but do two Senator represent the mood of the whole Senate or the will of the Roman people?  Besides, every truce we make with the Germans they break!

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: They won't break this one.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Apparently my opinion wasn't needed.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: Where is my family?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Cooperate and they will be returned to your estate.  I could have executed you.

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: And my army would have thrown your body into the Danube.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: The army is a problem.  They love you.  You have led them from victory to victory in the name of Rome and they love you.  And after all, you're just a hothead acting from a misguided sense of loyalty -- who could fault you for that?  Thus have I reached a compromise with the Senate over your fate: instead of executing you, I'm sending you to Rome where you will be tried...

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: On what charge?

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Endorse me in public.  Do that and I'll make you rich and set you free. I'll return your estates.  I know you would give anything to be outside again.  Endorse me and you will be free.  Think of it.  What would you do with your freedom?

turns.speaker: NARCISSUS
turns.text: If you set me free I will find my way back to the army, march on Rome and depose you.  Then, the army and I will restore the Republic so that animals like you will never control human destinies again.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: Insubordination.  To the Emperor... and the Senate.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Quintus will tell the army that you are being called to Rome to celebrate your victory.  They will hear that you are living in luxury. He will let them feel you have betrayed them for the good life. And soon the army won't even remember your name.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: The Senate is out to sink you.  I swear it, Caesar, your generosity is being repaid with public attacks on your honor.  Your enemies want you weak enough so by the first of Janus when you must be confirmed the Senate will be able to deny you.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: How can they?  Who else is there?  I have no heir...

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: Caesar, ignore them.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Ignore that?!  The sooner we leave this disgusting place the better.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: At least stay for the running of the animals.  You are paying for it you know...

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Gods of hell!  This must cost a fortune!  How many days is this going to go on?

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: Until your confirmation date.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: And like children everywhere they scream "freedom" the most when they desire it least.  I beg you, please continue, Caesar.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: At the opening of the month of Janus, I will ask this noble body to confirm my emperorship...

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Throw it down into the streets! Down into the Forum.  If it's my father they want then give him to them!

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: Yes.  You know, that's not a bad idea.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Maybe it'll crush Gaius.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: I'm serious.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: So am I.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: We can crush Gaius another way. What if you do throw something to the people they really want?  Make them a gift of food.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Give away food?

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: Sacks of grain, even bread.  I own the grain licenses for the military, I can arrange to divert a shipment bound for the army of the Danube.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: Take grain away from the army?

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: Make a gift to the people.  It's your money anyway so it's only fair.

turns.speaker: FALCO
turns.text: Caesar, let me sponsor your first wager in the arena.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I wouldn't know who to bet on.

turns.speaker: QUINTUS
turns.text: Gladly, Caesar.  And, if you'd like we can take you for a tour of the front at first light.

turns.speaker: COMMODUS
turns.text: I'm certain father will be in better humors by then.  Now, honor us with your presence at dinner.  I'll join you as soon as I see my father's physician.
